facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 30, 1954, of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 540 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated March 31, 1951, of the Court of the Additional Civil Judge, Mathura, in Suit No. 19 of 1950. C. Mathur, for the appellants. B. Aggarwala and Ganpat Rai, for the respondent. 1958. December 5.

facts.text: In 1938 the respondent took on rent the accommodation in dispute termed a tal on a monthly agreed rent of Rs. 21-4 as. and was using the same for stacking timber.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of this appeal are that in 1938 the respondent took on rent the accommodation in dispute which is termed a tal on a monthly agreed rent of Rs. 21-4 as. and was using the same for the purpose of stacking timber. A portion of it was a companyered godown which had three walls and a kucha roof.

facts.text: A portion of the accommodation was a companyered godown which had three walls and a kucha roof.

anchor.surface_text: A portion of it was a companyered godown which had three walls and a kucha roof. III of 1947   hereinafter termed the Act  for the fixation of reasonable annual rent of the accommodation in dispute.

facts.text: On January 28, 1950, the appellant made an application to the House Allotment Officer under s. 3-A of the Act for fixation of reasonable annual rent.

facts.text: Appellant alleged that in January 1949 he had constructed anew a big godown 80 x 25 x 11 feet according to instructions of the respondent and expended large sum, entitled to Rs. 165 monthly.

anchor.surface_text: He therein alleged that in January 1949 he had companystructed anew a big godown 80 x 25 x 11 feet according to the instructions of the respondent and expended a fairly large sum of money on it and was therefore entitled to a monthly rent of Rs. 165.

facts.text: House Allotment Officer fixed rent at Rs. 35 per mensem on February 18, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The House Allotment Officer fixed on February 18, 1950, the rent at Rs. 35 per mensem which on review was raised on May 25, 1950, to Rs. 40 per mensem.

facts.text: On review, rent raised to Rs. 40 per mensem on May 25, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: which on review was raised on May 25, 1950, to Rs. 40 per mensem. He held that the accommodation was number a newly companystructed accommodation as the respondent had been a tenant from 1938.

facts.text: HAO held accommodation not newly constructed as tenant from 1938, determined increase based on added building.

anchor.surface_text: He held that the accommodation was number a newly companystructed accommodation as the respondent had been a tenant from 1938. He determined the increase of rent on the basis of the building that was added by the new companystruction.

facts.text: Appellant instituted suit under s. 5(4) of the Act for inadequacy of reasonable annual rent.

facts.text: Additional Civil Judge held suit maintainable, newly constructed accommodation bigger and more spacious, increased rent to Rs. 55-8-0.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Civil Judge found that the suit was number barred because of the Act that the suit against the order of the House Allotment Officer was maintainable that newly companystructed accommodation on the whole was bigger and more spacious than the old kacha hall and that the accommodation had increased and after taking into companysideration the amount spent on the companystruction be increased the reasonable adequate rent to Rs. 55-8-0.

facts.text: High Court allowed revision, held construction on upper storey new but for respondent's accommodation not new construction, s.3A not applicable, suit dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the opinion that if the accommodation was a new companystruction erected after June 30, 1946, the suit was maintainable and- the High Court companyld number interfere with the finding of the Civil Judge as to the amount of rent. ... The revision petition was therefore allowed and the suit of the appellant was dismissed.

facts.text: Main controversy: whether High Court could interfere in revision under s.115 CPC with trial court's decision on date of construction.

facts.text: Appellant contended that date of construction was within jurisdiction of trial court, HC cannot interfere if erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytended that it was within the jurisdiction of the Additional Civil Judge to decide the question of the date of companystruction of the accommodation and in doing so he companyld decide rightly or wrongly as the matter was within his jurisdiction and therefore the High Court had numberpower to interfere merely because in its opinion the decision was erroneous.

facts.text: Respondent contended date of construction is jurisdictional fact; unless new after June 30, 1946, no right to suit under s.5(4).

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 5, 1958 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. December 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the decision of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad passed in revision under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

issues.text: whether the High Court could, in revision under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure, interfere with this decision of the trial court

anchor.surface_text: The main controversy raised between the parties was whether the High Court could, in revision under S. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure, interfere with this decision of the trial court. The respective contentions were these The appellant contended that it was within the jurisdiction of the Additional Civil Judge to decide the question of the date of construction of the accommodation and in doing so he could decide rightly or wrongly as the matter was within his jurisdiction and therefore the High Court had no power to interfere merely because in its opinion the decision was erroneous.

issues.text: the question for determination was whether the accommodation had been constructed before or after June 30, 1946

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in our view, approached the question quite correctly when it stated that the question for determination was whether the accommodation had been constructed before or after June 30, 1946, and that if it was constructed before that date the suit was incompetent and if after, the suit would lie.

issues.text: whether the decision of the court as to the date of construction was in this case a jurisdictional fact i.e. a fact which went to the root of the jurisdiction of the court

anchor.surface_text: The respondents counsel on the other hand submitted that the decision of the court as to the date of construction was in this case a jurisdictional fact i.e. a fact which went to the root of the jurisdiction of the court because unless the accommodation was held to have been a new construction made after June 30, 1946, the appellant would be bound by the agreed rent and would have no right of suit under s. 5(4) and the court would have no jurisdiction to entertain the suit.

issues.text: as to whether the High Court had correctly interfered under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure with the order of the Civil Judge

arguments.claim: It was within the jurisdiction of the Additional Civil Judge to decide the date of construction rightly or wrongly, so High Court had no power to interfere in revision merely because it thought the decision erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended that it was within the jurisdiction of the Additional Civil Judge to decide the question of the date of construction of the accommodation and in doing so he could decide rightly or wrongly as the matter was within his jurisdiction and therefore the High Court had no power to interfere merely because in its opinion the decision was erroneous.

arguments.court_reasoning: Date of construction is a jurisdictional fact; falls under category where tribunal decides preliminary facts giving jurisdiction, distinguishable from mere factual errors.

arguments.claim: House Allotment Officer decided date of construction in favour under s.3-A, establishing right to suit, so High Court cannot review correctness in revision under s.115 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: He also contended that the House Allotment Officer having decided in his favour the question of the date of construction which s. 3-A of the Act authorises him to decide, his right to bring the suit was established and therefore the High Court could not in revision under s. 115, Code of Civil Procedure, go into the correctness of that decision.

arguments.claim: Under Act scheme, s.5(4) suit by landlord for inadequate reasonable rent requires new construction after June 30, 1946 as jurisdictional fact; agreed rent otherwise binding.

anchor.surface_text: In order to decide the question at issue, it is necessary at this stage to refer to the scheme of the Act. The object of the Act was to control letting and the rents of residential and non-residential accommodations. Accommodation was defined in s. 2(a) as follows...

arguments.claim: Date of construction is jurisdictional fact; trial court erred, exercised jurisdiction not vested; High Court can interfere under s.115 CPC per precedents like Joy Chandlal.

arguments.claim: Distinguishes cases where tribunal has jurisdiction to decide preliminary facts; here legislature confers jurisdiction only if new construction exists, not to decide it.

holdings.text: The date of construction of the accommodation (whether before or after June 30, 1946) is a jurisdictional fact for maintainability of a landlord's suit under s.5(4) of the U.P. Act III of 1947 claiming inadequacy of reasonable annual rent.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of the Act restricts landlord's suit under s.5(4) to inadequacy of reasonable annual rent defined under s.2(f) for post-1946 constructions via s.3-A; pre-1946 binds to agreed rent, no enhancement suit.

holdings.text: High Court can interfere in revision under s.115 CPC if subordinate court erroneously decides jurisdictional fact, thereby exercising jurisdiction not vested in it.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes two classes of jurisdictional cases per Lord Esher; here legislature confers jurisdiction only if post-1946 construction exists, not power to decide preliminary fact; follows Privy Council precedents like Joy Chandlal where error on jurisdictional fact allows revision.

holdings.text: The trial court's finding of new construction was erroneous; accommodation in respondent's occupation was not newly constructed after June 30, 1946, rendering suit incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in our view, approached the question quite correctly when it stated that the question for determination was whether the accommodation had been constructed before or after June 30, 1946, and that if it was constructed before that date the suit was incompetent and if after, the suit would lie.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Approves High Court's analysis that upper storey new but tenant's tal/godown not new construction post-1946; trial court erred on this jurisdictional fact.

holdings.text: Suit under s.5(4) is maintainable notwithstanding prior fixation of rent by House Allotment Officer under s.3-A.

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the result of any suit filed under sub- section (4) of section 5, the rent fixed by the District Magistrate under this section shall be the annual reasonable rent of the accommodation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit language of s.3-A(3) makes HAO order subject to s.5(4) suit; confirms trial court's holding on this point.

holdings.text: Landlord cannot sue under s.5(4) to enhance agreed rent for pre-July 1, 1946 accommodation; restricted to challenging inadequacy of reasonable annual rent.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive reading of Act's scheme: s.5(1) agreed rent governs unless varied specifically; s.5(4) only for reasonable rent inadequacy post s.3-A for qualifying accommodations.

precedents.citation: Queen v. Commissioner for Special Purposes of the Income Tax

anchor.surface_text: Queen v. Commissioner for Special Purposes of the Income Tax 1 - When an inferior companyrt or tribunal or body, which has to exercise the power of deciding facts, is first established by Act of Parliament, the legislature has to companysider, what powers it will give that tribunal or body.

precedents.case_name: Queen v. Commissioner for Special Purposes of the Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Two classes of cases regarding inferior courts' jurisdiction over preliminary facts: one where tribunal decides the fact, no appeal if wrong; other where fact must exist independently.

precedents.citation: Venkatagiri Ayyangar v. Hindu Religious Endowment Board, Madras

anchor.surface_text: Per Sir John Beaumont in Venkatagiri Ayyangar v. Hindu Religious Endowment Board, Madras 1 . Therefore if an erroneous decision of a subordinate companyrt resulted in its exercising jurisdiction number vested in it by law or failing to exercise the jurisdiction so vested or acting with material irregularity or illegality in the exercise of its jurisdiction the case for the exercise of powers of revision by the High Court is made out.

precedents.case_name: Venkatagiri Ayyangar v. Hindu Religious Endowment Board, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court can interfere in revision under s.115 CPC if subordinate court exercises jurisdiction not vested, fails to exercise vested jurisdiction, or acts illegally/with material irregularity.

precedents.citation: Joy Chand Lal Babu v. Kamalaksha Chaudhury

anchor.surface_text: In Joy Chand Lal Babu v. Kamalaksha Chaudhury 2 , the subordinate companyrt gave an erroneous decision that the loan was a companymercial loan and therefore refused to exercise jurisdiction vested in it by law and the Privy Council held that it was open to the High Court to interfere in revision under s. 115.

precedents.case_name: Joy Chand Lal Babu v. Kamalaksha Chaudhury
precedents.cited_proposition: Erroneous decision by subordinate court refusing jurisdiction on jurisdictional fact allows High Court interference in revision under s.115(b) CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The cases of Babu Ram v. Munnalal 1 and Hari Bhikaji v. Naro Vishvanath 2 , may be mentioned as cases in which a subordinate companyrt by its own erroneous decison erroneous, that is, in the view of the High Court , in the one case on a point of limitation and in the other on a question of res judicata, invested itself with a jurisdiction which in law it did number possess and the High Court held, wrongly their Lordships think, that it had numberpower to interfere in revision to prevent such a result.

precedents.cited_proposition: Cases where subordinate courts erroneously assumed jurisdiction but High Courts wrongly declined revision.

anchor.surface_text: Babu Ram v. Munnalal 1 and Hari Bhikaji v. Naro Vishvanath 2 , may be mentioned as cases in which a subordinate companyrt by its own erroneous decison erroneous, that is, in the view of the High Court , in the one case on a point of limitation and in the other on a question of res judicata, invested itself with a jurisdiction which in law it did number possess

precedents.cited_proposition: Case where subordinate court erroneously assumed jurisdiction on res judicata but High Court declined revision (disapproved).

precedents.citation: Keshardeo Chamria v. Radha Kissen Chamria

anchor.surface_text: In Keshardeo Chamria v. Radha Kissen Chamria 3 both these judgments of the Privy Council as also the previous judgments in Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh 4 and Balakrishna Udayar v. Vasudeva Aiyar 5 were reviewed and it was held that s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure applies to matters of jurisdiction alone, the irregular exercise or number exercise of it or the illegal assumption of it.

precedents.case_name: Keshardeo Chamria v. Radha Kissen Chamria
precedents.cited_proposition: S.115 CPC applies to jurisdictional errors: illegal assumption, non-exercise, or irregular exercise of jurisdiction.

precedents.citation: Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh

anchor.surface_text: previous judgments in Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh 4 and Balakrishna Udayar v. Vasudeva Aiyar 5 were reviewed and it was held that s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure applies to matters of jurisdiction alone, the irregular exercise or number exercise of it or the illegal assumption of it. Thus if a subordinate companyrt had jurisdiction to make the order it made and has number acted in breach of any provision of law or companymitted any error of procedure which is material and may have affected the ultimate decision, then the High Court has numberpower to interfere.

precedents.case_name: Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Prior judgment reviewed in Keshardeo on scope of s.115 CPC regarding jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh 4 and Balakrishna Udayar v. Vasudeva Aiyar 5 were reviewed and it was held that s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure applies to matters of jurisdiction alone, the irregular exercise or number exercise of it or the illegal assumption of it.

precedents.cited_proposition: Prior judgment reviewed in Keshardeo on scope of s.115 CPC regarding jurisdiction.

precedents.citation: Rai Brij Raj Krishna v. S. K. Shaw and Bros.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also relied on Rai Brij Raj Krishna v. S. K. Shaw and Bros. 6 where this Court quoted with approval the observations of Lord Esher in Queen v. Commissioner for Special Purposes of the Income Tax 7 and The Colonial Bank of Australia v. Willan where Sir James Co ville said -

precedents.case_name: Rai Brij Raj Krishna v. S. K. Shaw and Bros.
precedents.cited_proposition: Adjudication by judge with jurisdiction is conclusive on facts unless defect on face; no certiorari on erroneous fact finding.

precedents.citation: The Colonial Bank of Australia v. Willan
precedents.case_name: The Colonial Bank of Australia v. Willan
precedents.cited_proposition: Adjudications with jurisdiction are conclusive on facts; no quashing on erroneous findings via certiorari.

precedents.citation: Joy Chand Lal Babu v. Kamalaksha Chaudhury

anchor.surface_text: the matter fell within the rule laid down by the Privy Council in Joy Chandlal Babu v. Kamalaksha Chaudhury 1 .

precedents.case_name: Joy Chand Lal Babu v. Kamalaksha Chaudhury
precedents.cited_proposition: Rule allowing High Court revision when subordinate court exercises jurisdiction not vested due to erroneous jurisdictional fact.
